title: 113_hr2956
content: The Act titled "End Welfare for Big Oil Act of 2013" aims to repeal oil and gas subsidies, specifically targeting major integrated oil companies with modifications to foreign tax credit rules. The "End Welfare for Big Oil Act of 2013" proposes changes to foreign tax credit rules for major integrated oil companies, excluding certain payments to foreign countries without income taxes from being considered as taxes. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to a person who pays income tax in a foreign country or possession, or would pay if the tax applied to them. This does not affect amounts determined under a specific subparagraph. The term 'generally applicable income tax' refers to an income tax imposed by a foreign country or possession on income from a trade or business conducted within that country or possession. The term 'generally applicable income tax' excludes taxes that do not apply to individuals who are not dual capacity taxpayers or citizens/residents of the foreign country or possession. The amendments apply to taxes paid in taxable years after the enactment date, except where they conflict with US treaty obligations. SEC. 102 limits the Section 199 deduction for oil, natural gas, or related products for major integrated oil companies starting after December 31, 2013. SEC. 103 amends the Internal Revenue Code to limit deductions for intangible drilling and development costs for major integrated oil companies. This amendment applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2013. SEC. 104 limits the percentage depletion allowance for oil and gas wells for major integrated oil companies. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2013. SEC. 105 limits the deduction for tertiary injectants. SEC. 105 limits the deduction for tertiary injectants for major integrated oil companies, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2013. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 is being amended to repeal sections 344 and 345 related to royalty relief for outer continental shelf deep water and deep gas. Any savings from this repeal will be used for deficit reduction or reducing the federal debt.
